quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we talk about how to build and maintain momentum within your organization, how sometimes slowing growth down is the best way to grow long term,
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive growth principle practitioners can apply: deliberately slowing down can enable stronger long-term growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: why the most innovative ideas often come from people with no experience in the problem space,
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Suggests a hiring/ideation mental model: outsiders can generate more innovative solutions than domain experts.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: why manufacturing fake deadlines is so powerful and effective and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a practical execution tactic teams can use to create urgency and drive delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta read)
quotes.context: Concrete adoption and impact metrics that quantify how much compliance work can be automated.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: By offering the most in-demand security and privacy frameworks such as SOC 2, ISO 27001, GDPR, HIPAA, and many more, Vanta helps companies obtain the reports they need to accelerate growth, build efficient compliance processes, mitigate risks to their businesses, and build trust with external stakeholders.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta read)
quotes.context: A practical checklist of common compliance frameworks and the business outcomes they support (growth, risk reduction, trust).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Element is a tasty electrolyte drink mix with a science-backed electrolyte ratio.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Element read)
quotes.context: Highlights an evidence-based approach (ratio) as a selection criterion rather than marketing claims.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Getting enough electrolytes helps prevent and eliminate headaches, muscle cramps, fatigue, sleeplessness, and other common symptoms of electrolyte deficiency.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Element read)
quotes.context: Actionable health guidance linking electrolyte intake to specific, common symptoms practitioners can monitor.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb roles and learning supply-as-product
quotes.text: Our product really wasn't our technology. It wasn't the technology that we were building, although for a few years we all thought it was.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing for marketplace/software teams: the real product may not be the tech, even if the company assumes it is.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb roles and learning supply-as-product
quotes.text: If anything, Airbnb's product was its hosts.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for marketplaces: treat supply (hosts) as the core product to invest in and improve.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb roles and learning supply-as-product
quotes.text: I think it maybe just starts internally where you have to be able to create a culture first, to all understand that.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Actionable advice: aligning internal culture around the true “product” is a prerequisite to making the right product and growth decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb roles and learning supply-as-product
quotes.text: Because otherwise you're going to be in a position where you're focused on optimizing the technology, efficiency, growth, looking at tools for tools' sake versus tools for users' sake.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A practical warning about a common failure mode—building tools that optimize internal metrics rather than user outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb roles and learning supply-as-product
quotes.text: If we put the hosts first and we thought about building tools for them versus what do we need just to drive more bookings, users begets users, and that's exactly what we saw.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A growth playbook for marketplaces: prioritize supply-side success and growth follows as a second-order effect.

quotes.topic_title: Culture, energy, and storytelling as leverage
quotes.text: It is bread and butter to everything you do, from the people you hire to how you build the right mindset to just keeping the energy. I mean, energy at Airbnb was the currency.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Frames “energy” as a tangible organizational resource you must actively generate and maintain, not a vague cultural byproduct.

quotes.topic_title: Culture, energy, and storytelling as leverage
quotes.text: I now reflect back on just how powerful our storytelling was at Airbnb to get people pumped up. I mean, even for some of the smallest features that we would build, Lenny, they would kick off with the most powerful storytelling.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A concrete practice: use mission-level storytelling to launch even small features to drive alignment and motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Culture, energy, and storytelling as leverage
quotes.text: I think one of the biggest ones I would say is that you need to get to know people personally as much as you do professionally.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Actionable culture-building guidance: invest in personal connection as deliberately as professional collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Culture, energy, and storytelling as leverage
quotes.text: For example, we make sure that we take time to have personal and professional check-ins.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Specific mechanism for remote culture: formalize both personal and professional check-ins to create stronger cross-functional bonds.

quotes.topic_title: Culture, energy, and storytelling as leverage
quotes.text: But no matter what, I do believe building personal connections and actually caring about the people you work for is imperative for building a lasting business.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Counters purely transactional views of work by asserting that care and connection are core to durability, not “nice-to-have.”

quotes.topic_title: From Airbnb to Bobbie: risk and conviction
quotes.text: And it's a big thing to take a risk because you're taking 10 steps backwards in hopes of making major leaps forward.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A vivid mental model for how meaningful career bets often feel like regression before they create outsized upside.

quotes.topic_title: From Airbnb to Bobbie: risk and conviction
quotes.text: I don't believe there's such a thing as taking a big leap without first taking a major risk,
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that links “big leaps” directly to accepting real downside rather than seeking risk-free progress.

quotes.topic_title: From Airbnb to Bobbie: risk and conviction
quotes.text: Some of them I still dream of doing one day, but a big reason for not taking the risk is because I didn't feel the conviction.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Highlights conviction as a gating criterion for which ideas are worth the risk, even when many options exist.

quotes.topic_title: From Airbnb to Bobbie: risk and conviction
quotes.text: I think I put a lot of intention into researching the marketplace, understanding the business, determining how much of a risk I'm really able to take, even financially.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A practical checklist for de-risking big moves through research and explicit risk budgeting.

quotes.topic_title: From Airbnb to Bobbie: risk and conviction
quotes.text: It certainly isn't what sometimes it can appear on the surface, which is, "Oh, she had an idea and she left." There's a lot of work that goes into determining is this actually going to be something that's viable?
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Counters the “impulsive founder leap” narrative by emphasizing the hidden diligence behind seemingly bold transitions.

quotes.topic_title: What Bobbie is and why it exists
quotes.text: It's one of the last remaining industries in the CPG space that has seen any disruption or change in probably 40 years.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A clear disruption thesis: look for large, stagnant categories where incumbents haven’t innovated in decades.

quotes.topic_title: What Bobbie is and why it exists
quotes.text: And my desire was to create a formula that parents could feel proud of, an infant formula that felt modern and met where science is today.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A product positioning framework: build around customer pride + modernity + alignment with current science.

quotes.topic_title: What Bobbie is and why it exists
quotes.text: I just hated the product and I couldn't understand why, as something that is used by so many, 83% of parents, why is it that I'm embarrassed about it?
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Highlights a high-usage category with negative emotion—an actionable signal for brand and product redesign opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: What Bobbie is and why it exists
quotes.text: I feel like we have failed to breastfeed.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Captures the stigma-driven customer pain that can be addressed through messaging, community, and brand purpose.

quotes.topic_title: What Bobbie is and why it exists
quotes.text: The first question all investors ask is what do you believe your growth is going to be? First question. It's the same question you get after you're married, when are you going to have a baby?
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A memorable analogy practitioners can use to frame (and defuse) early-stage forecasting pressure with stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: Formula shortage crisis and choosing to stop growth
quotes.text: Infant formula is one of those products you can't run out of. It's not cool to be out of infant formula. It's not like a piece of furniture and you're at capacity for a certain amount of time.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for tailoring growth and inventory decisions to the stakes and substitutability of the product category.

quotes.topic_title: Formula shortage crisis and choosing to stop growth
quotes.text: "Here's the dilemma. We are depleting inventory far quicker than our ability to replenish. And the customers keep coming."
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic framing that practitioners can use to recognize when demand growth is creating an existential fulfillment risk.

quotes.topic_title: Formula shortage crisis and choosing to stop growth
quotes.text: "So we need to turn off our site and stop growing the business."
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive but actionable move: deliberately pause acquisition to protect existing customers when supply can’t keep up.

quotes.topic_title: Formula shortage crisis and choosing to stop growth
quotes.text: For six months, six months, we kept our website off and we didn't grow the business last year and we continued to serve our current subscribers and in the end we became the only formula company that was able to reliably serve its current customers and never run out.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A concrete example and time-bound data point showing how prioritizing reliability and trust can outperform growth during a crisis.

quotes.topic_title: Formula shortage crisis and choosing to stop growth
quotes.text: So we named the entire growth team, the slowth team.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A memorable culture tactic for reorienting a growth org toward retention and constraint-driven execution (“slowth”).

quotes.topic_title: Brand building: meet customers where they are
quotes.text: Think about who your customer is and that one customer, the exact person, is going to wake up tomorrow morning and there's going to be three things that are just playing on them in the back of their mind, the things that keep them up at night. And if you are not solving for one of those, then you're going to be finding a way to build a brand and to get in the way of that, get in the way of their mindset, have them remember who you are or what you're about.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A simple “top 3 anxieties” mental model for ensuring brand messaging aligns with what customers already care about.

quotes.topic_title: Brand building: meet customers where they are
quotes.text: I have no desire to bombard people with something that isn't part of those top three things that they're experiencing. Otherwise, we will have companies out there and brands out there being loud for no reason.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A practical filter for deciding what not to say in marketing: avoid noise that doesn’t map to core customer pain.

quotes.topic_title: Brand building: meet customers where they are
quotes.text: If you're explaining, you're losing.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for positioning: if your message requires heavy justification, you’re likely targeting the wrong audience or framing.

quotes.topic_title: Brand building: meet customers where they are
quotes.text: And I'm not there to try and convince them. I think a part of this is amplifying those that are in need of our products, that are the 83% using formula and make sure that they feel heard.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive go-to-market choice: don’t waste effort converting entrenched skeptics—serve the majority already in the category.

quotes.topic_title: Brand building: meet customers where they are
quotes.text: No brand should ever be in a position of pointing fingers to something that's better or worse. Our only job, and I wish politics would also do this, our only job is to talk about what we do and why we exist and why we believe our product is good.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Clear guidance on brand strategy: focus on your own value proposition rather than attacking competitors or alternatives.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're looking to build AI-powered features in your audio and video products, then you need to know about Assembly AI, which makes it easy to transcribe and understand speech at scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical use case and positioning for teams building audio/video AI features: transcription and speech understanding at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What I love about Assembly AI is you can use their simple API to access the latest AI breakthroughs from top-tier research labs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Suggests a build strategy: leverage APIs to quickly benefit from cutting-edge research without building models in-house.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Product team that startups and enterprises are using assembly AI to automatically transcribe and summarize phone calls and virtual meetings, detect topics in podcasts, pinpoint when sensitive content is spoken and lots more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of high-value workflows (summarization, topic detection, sensitive-content detection) practitioners can apply.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: All of Assembly AI's models which are accessed through their API are production ready.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes deployability as a key selection criterion when choosing AI models/APIs for real products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Visit assemblyai.com/lenny to try their API for free and start testing their models with their no-code playground.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Encourages rapid experimentation via a no-code playground—useful for quick validation before engineering investment.

quotes.topic_title: Branding internal programs and the FDA setback
quotes.text: And really what an Air Dive was was an analysis of customer service tickets and customer service pain points. But how much better is Air Dive than a customer service analysis? So much better.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Shows how branding a mundane workflow can make it more engaging and memorable, increasing participation.

quotes.topic_title: Branding internal programs and the FDA setback
quotes.text: So I think a lot of learnings on just the power of branding and storytelling your workflows and your frameworks and what it means to do your job, often keeps people motivated, too. And it creates memory recall a lot better, too.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A practical internal-ops tactic: use naming and narrative to boost motivation and recall for repeatable processes.

quotes.topic_title: Branding internal programs and the FDA setback
quotes.text: So we created a program called the Secret Shopping Program, and our regulatory legal team go out and they do their own secret shopping once a month and then they report back on any misleading claims or ones that aren't fully understood that Bobbie needs to go back and update.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Concrete example of operationalizing compliance via a recurring program with a clear cadence and feedback loop.

quotes.topic_title: Branding internal programs and the FDA setback
quotes.text: It was early days, we just launched a pilot and the FDA showed up at our warehouse and they didn't like the way that we were labeling the product. We had to pull all of our product from the market, we had to relabel everything and we had to work with the agency for another year before we could bring our products back.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A vivid cautionary story about regulatory risk and the real cost/timeline impact of labeling and compliance mistakes.

quotes.topic_title: Branding internal programs and the FDA setback
quotes.text: So sometimes in moment of professional slowth, you might find that there's personal growth.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive morale/energy reframe: use professional slowdowns as space to lean into personal growth.

quotes.topic_title: Managing founder life with three kids
quotes.text: I'm introducing her because the power of a support system to be able to do what you do, I mean, you are an extension, my leverage, my everything. And never leave.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Highlights a practical leverage model: treating key support roles as force multipliers rather than “nice-to-haves.”

quotes.topic_title: Managing founder life with three kids
quotes.text: I will say it took multiple interviews and it's all about chemistry. I think it's about chemistry and finding somebody that you genuinely care about.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Actionable hiring guidance for an EA/support role: optimize for relationship fit and trust, not just skills.

quotes.topic_title: Managing founder life with three kids
quotes.text: I, as an operator, am very proud of the infrastructure I have built. I mean, we have calendars on our walls, we have calendars for our kids. We have back and forth birthday planning. It's additional help in the house.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Concrete example of “operationalizing” home life with visible systems and planning artifacts.

quotes.topic_title: Managing founder life with three kids
quotes.text: But that is, I think, the only way to get through the chaos and the only way to embrace the all, is you actually need to put in the work to build the infrastructure, the systems, the frameworks, and then every month, or sometimes in our case on a weekly basis, me and my husband, we have a meeting every Sunday and it's walking through the agendas.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Provides a repeatable methodology: build systems, then run a recurring weekly planning cadence to coordinate a dual-founder household.

quotes.topic_title: Managing founder life with three kids
quotes.text: Because you're right, a dual CEO-founder household and three kids, it will age you fast if you don't have it.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that “winging it” has compounding costs—structure is a necessity, not an optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Naivety, hiring generalists, and momentum
quotes.text: I think one of the biggest beliefs is that an ounce of naivety will be your biggest secret to success.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mental model: staying a bit “naive” can help you see white space and challenge entrenched assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Naivety, hiring generalists, and momentum
quotes.text: I think sometimes putting the most unlikely people who have an ounce of naivety to what it takes to win and succeed are the ones that are going to drive the biggest impact.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Hiring philosophy: generalists or “unlikely” candidates can outperform specialists by not being constrained by conventional playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Naivety, hiring generalists, and momentum
quotes.text: The secret is momentum and just keeping momentum. And if we try and perfect everything, you just miss the boat.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A practical operating principle for startups: prioritize speed and iteration over perfection to avoid losing timing advantages.

quotes.topic_title: Naivety, hiring generalists, and momentum
quotes.text: So I look for just optimistic doers.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A memorable hiring filter that emphasizes execution, ownership, and forward motion over credentials or pure strategy talk.

quotes.topic_title: Naivety, hiring generalists, and momentum
quotes.text: Our girl who leads marketing is an Emmy Award news anchor. She's not your traditional marketer.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A concrete example of hiring for adjacent strengths (storytelling/media) rather than the standard background for the role.

quotes.topic_title: D2C growth: content and community before commerce
quotes.text: D2C isn't dead. Just the approach for how people did D2C is a bit dated. We should not be paying for every customer and we should be very careful that people aren't getting hooked on the drug that is paid marketing or performance marketing.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Contrarian reframing that the channel isn’t broken—over-reliance on paid acquisition is, and it creates an addictive cost spiral.

quotes.topic_title: D2C growth: content and community before commerce
quotes.text: But most D2C businesses have put commerce at the top of their list. We flipped it. It's now content, community and commerce, and building good content that is really smart SEO, that has the ability to drive people back to your site to be able to build you as a thought leader.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: A practical growth framework for D2C: lead with SEO-driven content and community to create durable demand before pushing transactions.

quotes.topic_title: D2C growth: content and community before commerce
quotes.text: As an example, five years ago we started a platform called Milk Drunk, separate to Bobbie. Milk Drunk Blog. And the reason why we started it is because we realize that there was a dearth of education in the world of formula out there.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Concrete tactic: build a standalone educational content brand to fill an information gap and earn trust at the category level.

quotes.topic_title: D2C growth: content and community before commerce
quotes.text: If you do a cursory Google search for something like "How long does formula last?" Milk Drunk is showing up between the CDC and the bum on the first page of Google?
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Specific example of SEO as a long-term growth engine—ranking alongside authoritative sources signals credibility and drives organic acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: D2C growth: content and community before commerce
quotes.text: And in the meantime, I've had to squat away requests to put another 100,000, another 300,000 every month into paid marketing because the moment that drug starts, it's very easy to keep it going.
quotes.speaker: Laura Modi
quotes.context: Operational advice: resist escalating paid spend once it starts, because it becomes hard to stop and can crowd out sustainable channels.
